section.title: <b>Narrative tenses
section.sectiontitle: Use Past Simple and Past Continuous together to talk about an action that interrupts an ongoing situation.
section.text1a: I was talking to Jenny when there was a loud knock on the door.
section.text2a: We were playing chess when we first realised our daughter was a genius.
section.sectiontitle2: Use Past Perfect Simple to talk about completed actions that happened before another action in the past.
section.text3a: I was locked out because I had left my key at home.
section.text4a: I enjoyed Kubrick's film - I hadn't seen any of his work before.

section.title: Narrative tenses
section.sectiontitle: Use the Past Perfect Continuous to talk about actions or situations which continued up to the moment in the past that we are talking about.
section.text1a: They scored in the 80th minute. We had been playing well until that moment.
section.text2a: I moved to Dublin in 1996. I'd been living in Belfast before that.
section.sectiontitle2: Past Perfect Continuous is often used to show the reasons for a situation.
section.text3a: Why was her hair wet? Because she had been swimming.
section.text4a: Why was he tired? Because he'd been working all day.
